block.p: Report Assigns New Blame For Prisoner Abuses in Iraq A high-level Army investigation has found that military intelligence interrogators played a major role in ordering and carrying out the abuses of Iraqi prisoners, refuting earlier contentions that a handful of renegade military police guards were largely to blame.

Iraq's most powerful Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali Al-Sistani, returned to the country calling for a mass demonstration to end weeks of fighting between American forces and Shiite insurgents for control of Najaf. A march is being planned to the holy shrine that has been commandeered by fighters loyal to the upstart cleric, Moktada al-Sadr.

Some of the aggressive tactics used at Abu Ghraib appear to have their origins in shadowy corners of the campaign against terrorism, following techniques developed by Special Operations forces and the Central Intelligence Agency.

Palestinian Official Shot in Gaza The deputy chief of the Palestinian intelligence services was shot and seriously wounded in Gaza City. Two bodyguards were killed and two others were wounded as gunmen fired on his convoy, overturning one of the cars, and escaped.

Crash Investigation in Russia Russian investigators scrambled to discover what caused two passenger jets to crash almost simultaneously shortly after taking off from Moscow, killing at least 89 people and raising fears of terrorism. No clear causes emerged, leaving open the possibility of coincidence .

Zimbabwe Opposition's Protest Zimbabwe's leading opposition party declared that it would suspend its participation in upcoming parliamentary and local elections because the governing party, led by President Robert Mugabe, has effectively eliminated any chance of a fair vote. The opposition will take part only if new political reforms are adopted.

A Top Bush Aide Quits Over Ties to Kerry Foes Benjamin L. Ginsberg resigned as national counsel for President Bush's re-election campaign, a day after he acknowledged that he had provided legal advice to a veterans group that has leveled attacks on Senator John Kerry's war record.

Australian Faces War Tribunal David Hicks, who went from skinning kangaroos in Australia's outback to fighting for Islamic armies, appeared in a military court in Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba where he was charged with war crimes.

New Leader for Panel Representative Peter Hoekstra, of Michigan, who has expressed wariness about recommendations made by the Sept. 11 commission, was selected as chairman of the House intelligence committee.

U.S. Settles Suit Against Target The United States Department of Labor announced a $1.9 million settlement with a contractor for the Target Corporation after finding that the contractor had not paid overtime to hundreds of janitors.

Cheney Comments Draw Fire Leading social conservatives made clear their unhappiness that Vice President Dick Cheney expressed opposition to a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, a position in conflict with the Republican platform.

Shifting View on Climate The Bush administration, in a shift, delivered a report to Congress that focuses on research indicating that emissions of heat-trapping gases are the likely explanation for global warming.
Judge Rules Protesters Cannot Use Central Park A state judge ruled that organizers of the largest protest planned during the week of the Republican National Convention cannot rally in Central Park.

Some civil liberties groups are advising protesters to refuse to identify themselves to the police, despite a Supreme Court ruling that officers have a right to such information from people suspected of breaking the law.
Governor Pataki will get the opportunity to enter the national political stage next week when he introduces President Bush at the convention.

Fireproofing Test in Doubt Federal investigators looking into the collapse of the World Trade Center towers have found that the test that determines fireproofing sufficiency in buildings may be unable to predict what will happen in a fire.
New Gay Marriage Suit Filed A gay rights group that won a Massachusetts case legalizing gay marriage filed a suit in Connecticut.
First Gold Medal for Israel Gal Fridman, 28, received the best score after eleven windsurfing races, winning Israel's first gold medal since it began competing in the Olympics in 1952.

Doubts Over New Eye Drug Many doctors are questioning the effectiveness of Macugen, an experimental eye disease drug that has been a boon to its creator, as the drug nears approval by the Food and Drug Administration.
Auto Resale Value Declines Detroit's big rebates and interest-free financing deals have strengthened car sales for three years. But they have also eroded the resale value of many American cars.

More Scrutiny for KPMG KPMG, the accounting firm under scrutiny for promoting tax shelters that were found to be abusive, discussed selling a new shelter similar to a banned version more than two years after the Internal Revenue Service outlawed the original one, according to newly disclosed internal e-mail messages.
File Copy Network Searched Federal authorities conducted six searches in a move to disrupt a peer-to-peer file sharing network.
Editorials: Holding the Pentagon accountable; for religious bigotry; a digital divide.
